Fig. 1 BET isotherm curves of W-free ZrOH(H) and ZrOH(L) samples. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 X-ray photoelectron spectra of W-free ZrOH(H) and ZrOH(L) samples: (a) Zr 3d and (b) O 1s. The red circles represent the total fitting curves for individual splitted peak. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TGA-DSC curves of ZrOH(H) (black) and ZrOH(L) (grey) samples: (a) before and (b) after W loading. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 PXRD patterns of WZrOH(L) and WZrOH(H) catalysts; t=tetragonal ZrO2, m=monoclinic ZrO2, and w=monoclinic WO3. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Lewis and Brønsted acid site contents on a per-gram-catalyst basis of WZrOH(H) (closed symbols) and WZrOH(L) (open symbols) catalysts as a function of the calcination temperature. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) Lewis and (b) Brønsted acid site contents on a per-W-atom basis of WZrOH(H) (■) and WZrOH(L) (□) catalysts as a function of the W surface density. The inset represents the dependence of BET surface area on the W surface density for both catalyst series. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 HRTEM images of WZrOH(H) and WZrOH(L) samples, where t-ZrO2 =tetragonal ZrO2, m-ZrO2 =monoclinic ZrO2, m-WO3 =monoclinic WO3, and WO3 =surface mono-oxo W=O species and distorted Zr-stabilized WO3 NPs. (a) WZrOH(H)-723, (b) WZrOH(H)-873, (c) WZrOH(H)-1023, (d) WZrOH(H)-1073, (e) WZrOH(H)-1173, (f) WZrOH(L)-723, (g) WZrOH(L)-873, (h) WZrOH(L)-1023 and (i) WZrOH(L)-1173. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Raman spectra of (a) WZrOH(H) and (b) WZrOH(L) catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Activities of WZrOH(H) (■) and WZrOH(L) (□) catalysts as a function of the W surface density: (a) conversion of formic acid (XHCOOH) obtained by the experiments at 473K and (b) turnover rate (TOR) obtained by the experiments at 383K. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Correlation between the Brønsted acidity and the catalytic activities represented by (a) XCOOH and (b) TOR for WZrOH(H) (■) and WZrOH(L) (□) catalysts. Graphical abstract The precipitated zirconium oxyhydroxide, ZrOH(H), was used as a support for tungstate loading, where its specific surface area was 1.5-fold higher than that of the analogous sample obtained commercially, ZrOH(L). Due to this difference, crystalline WO3 and ZrO2 (tetragonal and monoclinic) were formed at a higher calcination temperature by 150K for WZrOH(H) than for WZrOH(L) when tungstate was loaded. For WO x /ZrO2 with different W surface densities produced by calcination at 723–1173K, pyridine-IR experiment and Raman spectroscopy revealed that more Brønsted acid sites were present for WZrOH(H) calcined at 1023 and 1073K than for WZrOH(L) calcined at 873K while distorted Zr-stabilized WO3 nanoparticles were found for these samples. Thus, the former samples showed the superior activity to the latter in the dehydration of formic acid. The linear relationship between the catalytic performance and Brønsted acidity was observed, explaining that WO x /ZrO2 with more Brønsted acid sites is more active in the dehydration reaction. Consequently, the enhanced Brønsted acidity and catalytic activity of WZrOH(H) resulted from the use of zirconium oxyhydroxide with a high surface area for tungstate loading. Keywords Zirconium oxyhydroxide High surface area Tungstated zirconia W surface density Brønsted acidity 1 Introduction Tungstated zirconia (WO x /ZrO2), developed first by Hino and Arata [1], has been considered to be an important solid acid catalyst due to superior properties such as thermal stability, strong acidity, and strong resistance upon exposure to H2, O2 and H2O. Particularly, WO x /ZrO2 is active at low temperatures in the isomerization of C4–C8 alkanes [2–5]; for instance, it showed better catalytic performance than zeolite β in the isomerization of n-pentane [6]. The superior activity of WO x /ZrO2 has been examined in other acid-catalyzed reactions including Mannich reaction [7], acylation [8], alkylation [9,10] and dimerization [11]. Besides, metal-promoted WO x /ZrO2 catalysts (metal: Pt, Pd, Au, Fe, etc.) has been studied in multi-step reactions requiring both metal and acid functions [12]. The acidity and catalytic performance of WO x /ZrO2 largely depends on W surface density varying with the activation temperature, the W loading and the nature of the starting Zr support. Boyse and Ko revealed three types of WO x clusters, such as mono-tungstate, poly-tungstate and crystalline WO3, of which each type is controlled by the activation temperature [13]. In terms of the tungstate loading, Scheithauer et al. found that the presence of WO x stabilized the tetragonal ZrO2 phase and increased the intrinsic BET surface area, and that a relatively dense overlayer containing W–O–W linkages and terminal W=O groups formed a three-dimensional network of interconnected WO6 octahedra near the theoretical monolayer coverage [14]. Soultanidis et al. related the n-pentane isomerization activity to the Zr support nature and the W surface density [15]. They claimed that amorphous zirconium oxyhydroxide (ZrO x (OH)4−2x ) was a better support than crystalline zirconia (ZrO2) and the best activity was obtained at 5–6W surface density (ρw,surf; W atoms nm−2) using ZrO x (OH)4−2x as a support. In their another work [16], ZrO x (OH)4−2x -supported WO x was more active than ZrO2-supported WO x in the dehydration of methanol to dimethyl ether and showed the best activity when the surface density was 6.2Wnm−2 (0.8–1nm tungstate cluster). Ross-Medgaarden et al. described the formation of Zr-stabilized distorted WO3 in nanoparticle sizes (NPs) in the monolayer region showing the best activity in methanol dehydration [17]. Distorted WO3 NPs were characterized by Raman absorption bands in the range 820–850cm−1 and 900–925cm−1. Meanwhile, it was proposed that the high acidity of WO x /ZrO2 originates from a conjugate Brønsted-Lewis site [18]. From these previous reports, it can be speculated that when ZrO x (OH)4−2x with a higher surface area is used, the final WO x /ZrO2 catalyst shows a larger amount of Brønsted/Lewis acid sites and thereby an improved activity in acid-catalyzed reactions. Thus, we herein have prepared ZrO x (OH)4−2x with a high surface area based on our recent work [19]. After the tungsten precursor was loaded into the resulting material by impregnation, the activation was conducted at different temperatures in order to vary the W surface density over WO x /ZrO2 catalysts. The prepared materials, ZrO x (OH)4−2x and WO x /ZrO2, were characterized by N2 physisorption, thermogravimetric analysis coupled with differential scanning calorimetry (TGA-DSC), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). In addition, the acid characteristics of WO x /ZrO2 catalysts were obtained by NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and pyridine-chemisorbed infrared spectroscopy (pyridine-IR). For the activity test, the decomposition of formic acid (HCOOH) was conducted because it is well known that acid catalysts exclusively promote the dehydration reaction (HCOOH→H2O+CO), but not the dehydrogenation reaction (HCOOH→H2 +CO2) mainly taking place over metal catalysts [20]. Finally, the measured activities of WO x /ZrO2 catalysts were correlated with their densities of Brønsted acid sites. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of amorphous zirconium oxyhydroxide ZrO x (OH)4−2x with a high surface area, labelled as ZrOH(H), was prepared by precipitation. An aqueous ammonia solution (28wt.% NH4OH, SK Chemical) was added dropwise into 0.5M aqueous zirconyl chloride (ZrOCl2·8H2O, Kanto Chemicals, 99%) at room temperature until the solution pH reached 9.2. Then, the mixed solution was refluxed at 373K for 72h, which is called “digestion”. The so-obtained filter cake was washed several times to eliminate chloride ions and dried at room temperature for 1day. For comparison, commercial ZrO x (OH)4−2x (purity 97%), labelled as ZrOH(L), was purchased from Sigma Aldrich. 2.2 Synthesis of tungstated zirconia catalysts WO x /ZrO2 catalysts were synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation of an aqueous solution of ammonium metatungstate hydrate ((NH)4H2W12O4·xH2O, Sigma Aldrich, 99.99%) onto the prepared ZrOH(H) and commercial ZrOH(L), where the W content was 15wt% in all samples. After drying at 378K overnight, crushing and sieving to less than 200μm, the W-loaded ZrOH(H) sample was calcined at a certain temperature for 4h in an air flow of 100mlmin−1 with a ramping rate 10Kmin−1. The resulting tungstated zirconia was named as WZrOH(H)-x, where x represents the calcination temperature of 723, 873, 1023, 1073 or 1173K. ZrOH(L) support was also used for W loading and the resulting catalyst was named as WZrOH(L)-x with x of 723, 873, 1023 or 1173 indicating the calcination temperature in a unit of Kelvin. 2.3 Characterization of the prepared samples PXRD patterns were acquired on a Rigaku SmartLab diffractometer using a Cu Kα radiation source (λ=0.154056nm, 45kV and 200mA). PXRD patterns were collected in the 2θ range 10–80° with a step increment of 0.02°. Micromeritics 3Flex instrument was used for measuring the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area at 77K after degassing of the sample (0.2g) at 298K for ZrO x (OH)4−2x or 373K for WO x /ZrO2 under vacuum for 1h. TGA-DSC measurement was conducted using a SDT Q600 (TA Instruments). The sample (ca. 10mg) was loaded on alumina pan and the temperature was raised from room temperature to 1273K with a heating rate 10Kmin−1 in a nitrogen gas flow 100mlmin−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a PHI Quantrea II (Ulvac-PHI) with a monochromatic Al Kα radiation. All spectra were calibrated using a standard C 1s binding energy of 248.6eV as reference. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) images were taken in a FEI Nova NanoSEM 450 microscope with an electron dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) operated in the range 10–15kV after the samples were coated by Pt. For high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) coupled with electron diffraction, a JEM 2100F microscope (JEOL) was used with a Gatan DigitalMicrograph imaging filter. Raman spectrometer (NRS-3100, JASCO) was used with 532nm laser excitation generated by a SOC green laser (output power=50mW, sample power=2.3mW). Raman spectra were obtained in the range 200–1200cm−1 with 1cm−1 resolution after vacuum drying of the sample disk at 368K for 1day to prepare a dehydrated sample. NH3-TPD experiment was conducted in an AutoChem 2910 (Micromeritics). Prior to the analysis, the sample was pretreated in a He flow of 30mlmin−1 at 523K for 2.5h. The sample was cooled to 373K and then exposed to 5% NH3/He flow of 30mlmin−1 for 30min. After acquiring a stable TCD baseline, the sample was heated to 1073K at a rate of 10Kmin−1, where the emitted gases were analyzed by a quantitative gas analyzer (Hiden Analytical). For pyridine-IR analysis, a Thermo Nicolet 6700 equipped with a MCT-A detector (Thermo Scientific) was used, where the spectrum was obtained with 32 scans at a resolution 4cm−1. The sample disk (50mg) was loaded inside a Specac HTHP cell and pretreated at 523K for 1.5h under vacuum. After pretreatment, the sample was cooled to 423K and exposed to 0.5μl pyridine at 423K for 30min. 2.4 Activity test The activity test was conducted in a quartz reactor into which the catalyst of 25mg was loaded. After pretreatment at 673K in a He flow and cooling to either 383K (at this temperature the conversion of HCOOH is below 5% in every runs) or 473K, an isothermal activity was obtained at a formic acid partial pressure of 5.7kPa. The feed stream was acquired by flowing 1% N2/He (100mlmin−1) into a Pyrex saturator containing formic acid (Sigma Aldrich) maintained at 298K for all runs. The product stream was connected to an on-line gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890B) equipped with a packed column (Porapak Q 80/100, 12ft×1/8 in×2.1mm) and a thermal conductivity detector. In order to prevent condensation of formic acid vapors, all stainless steel lines of 1/8 in. diameter were heated at 363–393K. The conversion of formic acid was calculated by the difference between the inlet and outlet molar flowrates of formic acid. Note that the selectivity to CO was 100% (i.e., no CO2 formation) for all tungstated zirconia catalysts used in this work. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of ZrOH(H) vs. ZrOH(L) The precipitated ZrO x (OH)4−2x sample prepared in this work and the commercial ZrO x (OH)4−2x sample were characterized prior to tungstate loading. PXRD analysis revealed that ZrOH(L) and ZrOH(H) samples are all X-ray amorphous (Fig. S1). When we measured their BET specific surface areas and pore volumes by N2 physisorption at 77K, ZrOH(H) showed higher textural properties than ZrOH(L): 414 vs. 280m2 g−1 for the BET surface area and 0.56 vs. 0.15cm3 g−1 for the single-point pore volume (Fig. 1 ). This difference is due to smaller particles of ZrOH(H) sample that was confirmed by FE-SEM images (Fig. S2). Since W-Zr interaction in the final tungstated zirconia catalysts may depend on the surface characteristics of the parent support, XPS was performed for Zr 3d and O 1s core levels. As shown in Fig. 2 a, Zr 3d3/2 (184.4eV) and Zr 3d5/2 (182.2eV) peaks are located at the same position for ZrOH(H) and ZrOH(L), and the area ratio of the two peaks is also same (Zr 3d3/2/3d5/2 =2/3). This explains no difference of Zr core level between the two samples. However, a little difference was found for the O 1s core level. Deconvolution work using the Gaussian features shows the two peaks at 529.7 and 531.1eV (Fig. 2b). Generally, the peak at the lower binding energy (peak 1) is attributed to surface lattice oxygen of metal oxides, while the other peak (peak 2) is a result of chemosorbed oxygen or surface hydroxyl species [21,22]. When the area of peak 2 (Area 2) was normalized by that of peak 1 (Area 1), a higher value of 2.1 was calculated for ZrOH(L) than for ZrOH(H) (1.7). This means that the former sample is OH rich at the surface relative to the latter. However, this difference is not considered to be significant, because the surface atomic compositions of zirconium and oxygen were very similar: Zr 20.65at.% and O 79.35at.% for ZrOH(L) and Zr 20.41at.% and O 79.59at.% for ZrOH(H). Since the glow exotherm is frequently observed for zirconium hydroxide [23], transformation of ZrOH(H) and ZrOH(L) samples into crystalline zirconia was investigated by TGA-DSC analysis (Fig. 3 ). Obviously, ZrOH(L) showed a large exothermic peak at 702K that is much lower than 913K for ZrOH(H). The better thermal stability of ZrOH(H) is attributed to the enhanced agglomeration of primary particles during the extended digestion (72h in this work), and the stronger network structure [24]. On the other hand, the weight loss was slightly higher for ZrOH(L) (22.8wt.%) than for ZrOH(H) (20.4wt.%), which agree with the normalized peak area ratio of O 1s features in the XPS result. The TGA results for zirconium oxyhydroxide samples holds for W-loaded samples (not calcined yet), as shown in Fig. 3b. However, the glow exotherm was not distinct for W-loaded ZrOH(L) although the very weak exotherm was shown at 720K, and it was largely shifted to 996K for W-loaded ZrOH(H), due to stabilization effect of W species [25]. 3.2 Characteristics of WZrOH(H) and WZrOH(L) catalysts ZrOH(H) and ZrOH(L) samples were loaded by tungsten species of 15wt% tungsten content, followed by calcination at different temperatures. In all PXRD patterns of WZrOH(L) catalysts, the reflections corresponding to tetragonal ZrO2 are shown (Fig. 4 a). This is supported by the DSC result of W-loaded ZrOH(L) sample; i.e., the lowest calcination temperature of 723K is higher than the glow exotherm temperature of W-loaded ZrOH(L), 720K. The reflections of monoclinic ZrO2 and monoclinic WO3 crystals were visible upon calcination of W-loaded ZrOH(L) at 1023K, and they were more intense for WZrOH(L)-1173. The similar structural change was found for WZrOH(H), however, the transition occurred at higher temperatures (Fig. 4b). The tetragonal ZrO2 phase was observed starting from WZrOH(H)-1023, which is valid because the exothermic DSC peak was observed around 996K for W-loaded ZrOH(H). The reflections of monoclinic ZrO2 were very weak for WZrOH(H)-1073 and WZrOH(H)-1173. Although the reflections of monoclinic WO3 phase were visible for these two samples, their intensities were much less than those for WZrOH(L) catalysts. This finding was still consistent for the spent catalysts, which was confirmed by PXRD patterns of the spent catalysts (Fig. S3). However, a little phase transformation of tetragonal to monoclinic ZrO2 was observed for some spent samples compared to the corresponding fresh ones. including WZrOH(L)-1023, WZrOH(L)-1173, WZrOH(H)-873, and WZrOH(H)-1173. Thus, the BET surface areas were measured for the spent catalysts, showing the small decrease in the range 3–10m2 g−1. This means that the prepared WZrOH samples are relatively stable under the reaction condition, due to the low reaction temperatures of 383 and 473K. The BET surface area values of WZrOH(H) and WZrOH(L) catalysts as a function of calcination temperature are given in Table 1 . The BET surface area decreased gradually with increasing the calcination temperature for both types of catalysts. The same trend was observed for the single-point pore volume. This is because amorphous zirconium oxyhydroxide supports sinter, crystallize and undergo pore collapse, as reported in the literature [26]. Also, the higher BET surface areas of WZrOH(H) compared to WZrOH(L) at the same calcination temperature are simply due to better thermal stability of ZrOH(H) support. Based on the measured BET surface area values, we calculated the tungsten surface density (ρ W,surf) in a unit of W-atoms nm−2 using the method described in the literature [17]. As summarized in Table 1, the ρ W,surf value increased with the calcination temperature; it ranges from 5.4 to 30.5 W-atoms nm−2 for WZrOH(L) and from 2.4 to 17.0 W-atoms nm−2 for WZrOH(H). At the same x values WZrOH(H) showed the lower ρ W,surf values than WZrOH(L) due to the higher BET surface areas of the former catalysts. The more interesting result to note is that the ρ W,surf values of WZrOH(L)-723, WZrOH(L)-873 and WZrOH(L)-1023 are comparable to those of WZrOH(H)-1023, WZrOH(H)-1073 and WZrOH(H)-1173, respectively. Since the W surface density affects the acidity of WO x /ZrO2 catalysts, NH3-TPD and pyridine-IR experiments were conducted to estimate the acid site contents of WZrOH(H) and WZrOH(L) catalysts. However, we failed to quantitatively measure the contents of acid sites for the prepared catalysts by NH3-TPD experiment using a TCD detector, because H2O molecules emitted in the temperature range 600–800K. Although a MS detector was used in further studies, all mass signals for m/z =17 and 18 were considered to be overlapped by desorbed H2O and NH3 (Fig. S4). Thus, pyridine-IR spectra were acquired for all samples, as presented in Fig. S5. The absorption bands centered at 1447, 1491 and 1607cm−1 are assigned to the vibrational modes of pyridine coordinated to Lewis acid (L) sites, while those at 1491, 1547 and 1638cm−1 originate from pyridinium ion adsorbed on Brønsted acid (B) sites [27]. In WO x /ZrO2 catalyst system, the B sites are likely hydroxyl groups (W–O–W–OH or Zr–O–W–OH) associated with W6+ and W5+ atoms, while the L sites are coordinatively unsaturated Zr4+ cations [28]. According to the report of Wane et al. [29], the bands at about 1447 and 1538cm−1 are used for quantification of L and B contents on a per-gram-catalyst or per-W-atom basis, respectively. In both WZrOH(H) and WZrOH(L) catalysts, the L site content decreased with increasing the calcination temperature (Fig. 5 ). However, WZrOH(H) contained more L sites than WZrOH(L) when the calcination temperature is same. This can be explained by the high surface area of the parent ZrOH(H) compared to ZrOH(L), resulting in reduced sintering of the support (cf. TGA-DSC results) and, accordingly, more open Zr sites (i.e., Lewis acidity). When normalized to the W surface density, the L site content (on a per-W-atom basis) of both catalysts decreased with increasing ρ W,surf and falls on the same correlation curve represented by the solid line (Fig. 6 a). This pattern is also similar to that for the BET surface area of the catalysts (Fig. 6a, inset), meaning again that the number of unsaturated Zr4+ cations being accessible as L surface sites is determined by the specific surface area of WO x /ZrO2 catalyst. The Brønsted acidity of WZrOH(H) and WZrOH(L) catalysts shows a volcano-shape dependence on the calcination temperature (Fig. 5). This is very different from the measured results for the Lewis acidity, although the finding is similar such that WZrOH(H) contained more B sites than WZrOH(L) when the calcination temperature is same. For WZrOH(H) catalysts, the B site content increased from 27.0 to 57.3–60.1μmolg−1 with the calcination temperature increasing from 723 to 1023–1073K, and then dropped to 25.5μmolg−1 for WZrOH(H)-1173. The similar trend was noticed for WZrOH(L) catalysts but the Brønsted acidity was estimated to be the highest (34.3μmolg−1) for WZrOH(L)-873, i.e., when calcined at the lower temperature of 873K. Even when normalized to the W surface density, the B site content of both catalysts on a per-W-atom basis shows the similar trend with increasing ρ W,surf (Fig. 6b). The B site content of 0.075±0.003 sites W−1 was found at ρ W,surf of 5.5 and 8.7 W-atoms nm−2 for WZrOH(H), which is higher by 40% than that of WZrOH(L)-873 showing 0.045 sites W−1 at ρ W,surf of 8.2 W-atoms nm−2. When compared to the B site contents of WZrOH samples (0.019–0.035 sites W−1) reported in Soultanidis et al. [15], WZrOH(L) catalysts show a little different Brønsted acidity due to difference in the calcination temperature affecting the surface polytungstate species [30]. However, the more significant difference is found for WZrOH(H) catalysts (0.033–0.079B sites W−1). This is possibly due to the high surface area of ZrOH(H) support (414m2 g−1), thus retarding the formation of WO3 crystals (favorable at higher calcination temperatures) resulting in the Brønsted acidity decrease [31]. This higher Brønsted acidity of WZrOH(H) catalysts would lead to a higher activity in the dehydration of formic acid (shown later). The location and crystallography of tungsten species for WZrOH samples were characterized by HRTEM (Fig. 7 ), where the enlarged version of all images are shown in Figs. S6 and S7 . As the calcination temperature increased for both types of catalyst samples, well-ordered crystalline WO3 particles were produced, e.g., for WZrOH(L)-1023, WZrOH(L)-1173, and WZrOH(H)-1173. However, the WZrOH samples calcined at low temperatures contained tiny WO3 nanoparticles showing no electron diffraction. In terms of ZrO2 crystallinity, monoclinic ZrO2 particles were observed in WZrOH(L)-1023 and WZrOH(L)-1173 while tetragonal ZrO2 particles existed in WZrOH(L)-723, WZrOH(L)-873, WZrOH(H)-1023, and WZrOH(H)-1073 samples. The findings from the HRTEM images match well with the PXRD results of WZrOH samples shown in Fig. 4. In order to distinguish different tungstate species in WO x /ZrO2 catalysts, Ross-Medgaarden et al. used Raman spectroscopy under dehydrated conditions: isolated surface mono-oxo W=O species (∼1000cm−1), polymeric surface mono-oxo W=O species (∼1020cm−1), distorted Zr-stabilized WO3 NPs (∼820–850cm−1 and ∼900–925cm−1), and well-ordered crystalline WO3 particles (∼805, ∼715 and ∼270cm−1) [17]. Fig. 8 displays the Raman spectra of WZrOH(H) and WZrOH(L) catalysts in the range 500–1200cm−1. WZrOH(H)-1073, WZrOH(H)-1173, WZrOH(L)-1023 and WZrOH(L)-1173 catalysts obviously exhibited the Raman bands of well-ordered crystalline WO3 particles. This indicates that crystallization of amorphous WO3 occurs above 1023 and 873K for WZrOH(H) and WZrOH(L), respectively, which is in good agreement with PXRD results. In contrast, weak vibrations in the range ∼780–860cm−1 and ∼910–1020cm−1 were observed in the Raman spectrum of WZrOH(H)-1023 catalyst. The similar feature was found for WZrOH(H)-1073 and WZrOH(L)-873 catalysts. Such Raman bands explain the presence of distorted Zr-stabilized WO3 NPs in these three catalysts. It is worth noting that the B site content was higher for WZrOH(H)-1023 and WZrOH(H)-1073 among WZrOH(H) catalysts, and for WZrOH(L)-873 among WZrOH(L) catalysts. For the catalysts with low W surface densities, WZrOH(H)-723, WZrOH(H)-873 and WZrOH(L)-723, there was only a broad Raman band centered around 940cm−1. Ross-Medgaarden and Wachs revealed that under ambient conditions where the surface is hydrated, the Raman bands at ∼945 and ∼955cm−1 is characteristic of aqueous distorted [WO4]2− and a combination of distorted aqueous [WO4]2− and aqueous [HW6O21]5−, respectively [32]. They also found that upon dehydration these bands are shifted to ∼1000 and ∼1010cm−1. Since the samples are assumed to be exposed to ambient conditions for several hours before acquiring Raman spectra though ex-situ dehydrated in this work, the band around 940cm−1 is associated with mono-oxo surface WO5 monotungstate and mono-oxo surface WO5/WO6 polytungstate species. These species are very general for WO x /ZrO2 catalysts with low W surface densities. 3.3 Activity of WZrOH(H) and WZrOH(L) catalysts in the dehydration of formic acid WZrOH(H) and WZrOH(L) catalysts were tested for the conversion of formic acid (HCOOH) into CO and H2O. It was believed that the dehydration reaction occurred exclusively over all catalysts, because CO2 was not produced in every run. In the first series of catalytic experiments, the reaction was conducted isothermally at 473K. As seen in Fig. 9 a, the conversion of formic acid (XHCOOH) shows a volcano-shape dependence on the W surface density. For WZrOH(H) catalysts, the superior performance (XHCOOH =ca. 89%) was obtained with WZrOH(H)-1023 and WZrOH(H)-1073 having the ρ W,surf of 5.9 and 7.6W-atoms nm−2, respectively. For WZrOH(L) catalysts, WZrOH(L)-873 (ρ W,surf =8.2 W-atoms nm−2) exhibited the high XHCOOH of 59%. However, the XHCOOH values were too high in comparing the catalytic activity, so that the second series of experiments were performed at a very low temperature of 383K. Since the XHCOOH values remained low (≤5%) in these runs, the condition was considered to be near differential. Thus, the HCOOH consumption turnover rate TOR [s−1] could be calculated by the number of HCOOH molecules reacted per tungsten atom per second, based on the report of Soultanidis et al. [15]. When the calculated TOR values were plotted against the W surface density (Fig. 9b), the similar trend as in Fig. 8a was found. In detail, WZrOH(H)-1023 and WZrOH(H)-1173 showed the much higher TOR values of 0.045–0.050s−1, whereas WZrOH(L)-873 exhibited the high TOR of 0.028s−1 among WZrOH(L) catalysts. It should be noted here that the TOR value was highest at ρ W,surf close to 8.0 W-atoms nm−2 for both WZrOH(H) and WZrOH(L) catalysts. While examining the catalytic results, we noticed that the activity trend follows a pattern in the plot of Brønsted acidity against ρ W,surf presented in Fig. 6b. Thus, XHCOOH and TOR values were correlated with B site content on a per-gram-catalyst basis for WZrOH(H) and WZrOH(L) catalysts. Fig. 10 clearly shows the linear relationship between the catalytic activity and Brønsted acidity with an excellent least squares fit (R 2 =0.995±0.002). In contrast, the relationships between the activity values and the contents of L site and total (B+L) site are not straightforward (Fig. S8). This indicates that the Brønsted acidity of WO x /ZrO2 catalysts is responsible for their catalytic activity in the dehydration of formic acid. Additionally, more B sites and thereby enhanced dehydration activity would be achieved when the tungstate is loaded onto the parent zirconium oxyhydroxide support of a high surface area, ZrOH(H). 3.4 Locations of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on WOx/ZrO2 catalysts From the results of the WZrOH samples investigated herein, a conceptual schematic is built to illustrate the locations of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on WOx/ZrO2 catalysts (Fig. 11 ). In this work the W surface density varied by changing the calcination temperature from 723 to 1173K, where the tungsten loading was the same at 15wt%. The higher calcination temperature resulted in the decrease in the BET surface area of WZrOH(L) and WZrOH(H) samples. It was remarkable that the Lewis site content in the two series of samples decreased with the very similar pattern to the BET surface area as the calcination temperature increased (Fig. 6a). This strongly suggests that unsaturated Zr4+ atoms are responsible for Lewis acidity. Since a tungsten-free ZrO2 sample was examined to contain only Lewis acid sites (not shown here), we believe that the number of Lewis acid site is diminished due to a lower specific surface area of ZrO2 support. On the other hand, the number of Brønsted acid site is relevant to the W surface density, meaning that hydroxyl groups associated with W6+ and W5+ atoms (W–O–W–OH or Zr–O–W–OH) function as Brønsted acid. As the W surface density increased, the tungsten surface species was changed in the following order: isolated surface mono-oxo W=O species<polymeric surface mono-oxo W=O species<distorted Zr-stabilized WO3 NPs<crystalline WO3 particles. Along with this change, WOx particles became larger. Because the number of Brønsted acid site is in the volcano-shape dependence with the W surface density (Fig. 6b), the Brønsted site content goes to a maximum when the W surface species is mainly in the form of distorted Zr-stabilized WO3 NPs and WO3 NPs where ρ W,surf is in the range 6.0–8.0W-atoms nm−2, and then declines due to the formation of larger crystalline WO3 particles. Consequently, it is strongly considered that Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of WOx/ZrO2 catalysts are located on surface tungsten species and ZrO2 support, respectively. 4 Conclusions We have herein examined the higher Brønsted acidity and enhanced HCOOH dehydration activity of WO x /ZrO2 catalysts, WZrOH(H), prepared using the precipitated ZrO x (OH)4−2x as a support for tungstate loading. Such results are attributed to the 1.5-fold higher specific surface area of ZrOH(H) compared to the commercial support ZrOH(L). This significant difference leads to the formation of well-ordered crystalline WO3 particles at the much higher calcination temperature for WZrOH(H) by 150K than for WZrOH(L) showing the crystallization above 873K. Thus, the higher Brønsted acidity is obtained upon calcination at 1023 and 1073K for WZrOH(H) and at 873K for WZrOH(L), where the B site content is higher by 40% for the former two samples than for WZrOH(L)-873. Also, the presence of distorted Zr-stabilized WO3 NPs is identified only in these three WO x /ZrO2 catalysts. Owing to the above catalyst characteristics, the activity (XCOOH and TOR) in the dehydration of HCOOH shows the volcano-shape dependence on the calcination temperature and, in turn, the W surface density. Furthermore, the relationship between the catalytic activity and Brønsted acidity is very linear, explaining that WO x /ZrO2 with more B sites will be a superior catalyst for the dehydration of formic acid. From all results we have investigated, it can be suggested that the study on the preparation of zirconium oxyhydroxide support with a high surface area is necessary for an active WO x /ZrO2 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The precipitated zirconium oxyhydroxide, ZrOH(H), was used as a support for tungstate loading, where its specific surface area was 1.5-fold higher than that of the analogous sample obtained commercially, ZrOH(L). Due to this difference, crystalline WO3 and ZrO2 (tetragonal and monoclinic) were formed at a higher calcination temperature by 150K for WZrOH(H) than for WZrOH(L) when tungstate was loaded. For WO x /ZrO2 with different W surface densities produced by calcination at 723–1173K, pyridine-IR experiment and Raman spectroscopy revealed that more Brønsted acid sites were present for WZrOH(H) calcined at 1023 and 1073K than for WZrOH(L) calcined at 873K while distorted Zr-stabilized WO3 nanoparticles were found for these samples. Thus, the former samples showed the superior activity to the latter in the dehydration of formic acid. The linear relationship between the catalytic performance and Brønsted acidity was observed, explaining that WO x /ZrO2 with more Brønsted acid sites is more active in the dehydration reaction. Consequently, the enhanced Brønsted acidity and catalytic activity of WZrOH(H) resulted from the use of zirconium oxyhydroxide with a high surface area for tungstate loading.
coredata.dc:title: Higher Brønsted acidity of WO x /ZrO2 catalysts prepared using a high-surface-area zirconium oxyhydroxide
